choices.C: A session for denied traffic is created.
choices.B: Denied users are blocked for 30 minutes.
choices.A: Device detection on all interfaces is enforced for 30 minutes.
choices.D: The number of logs generated by denied traffic is reduced.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Duration 30 is in seconds, not minutes.

Selected Answer: BC
It's B and C, it's even in the KB pollyy linked....

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

The exhibit shows a web filtering log.
Which statement about the log message is true?

choices.C: The action for the category Games is set to block.
choices.A: The web site miniclip.com matches a static URL filter whose action is set to Warning.
choices.D: The name of the applied web filter profile is default.
choices.B: The usage quota for the IP address 10.0.1.10 has expired.

choices.C: Port address translation is not used.
choices.A: The source IP is translated to the outgoing interface IP.
choices.B: This is known as many-to-one NAT.
choices.D: Connections are tracked using source port and source MAC address.

discussion.content: A & B are correct - Security_Manual-6.2, p.152

questions.question_text: Which two statements about firewall policy NAT using the outgoing interface IP address with fixed port disabled are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I belive that Cross certificates(bridge CA), because Basic constraints saying CA=True. It's not Root CA, because Field Issuer and Subject is different. It's not user certificate, because CA=True. And It's not subordinate, because Issuer and Subject different company.
My answer is C
Issued to, not issued from. The Subject tells you who it's issued to. In this case, a user. Answer is A: A user.

1. Whenever you see the "Ca=True", you should know that the certificate you're looking at belongs to a CA.
2. KeyUsage=keycertsign: What is the intended use of this certificate, answer=keycertsign...in my opinion this is self-explanatory, it is used to sign digital certificates...
This is another reason it's a CA....NOT a person.

B is Correct.

comments.content:
From my understanding CA:true means it is a CA. Not a root CA but a CA.
Path none means there is no other CA below it so I think it is a clearly a SUBORDINATED one.

questions.question_text: Which two actions are valid for a FortiGuard category-based filter, in a web filter profile, for a firewall policy in proxy-based inspection mode? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answers C&D is correct, Allow and Warning

C&D : "the actions available depend on the mode of inspection:
proxy : allow bloc monitor warning and authenticate
